title.narrative: INCREASED ACCESS TO INCLUSIVE BASIC EDUCATION

description.narrative: Children, including vulnerable children, from early childhood to adolescence, have increased access to inclusive basic education., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Girls and boys, in particular the most marginalized and those affected by humanitarian crises, are provided with inclusive and equitable qualityeducation and learning opportunities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Children, including vulnerable children, from early childhood to adolescence, have increased access to inclusive basic education.

description.narrative: With UNICEF support, approximatively 1,692 children with disabilities (872 boys and 820 girls) continued to access learning in 60 inclusive model schools and 189 inclusive cluster schools and in home settings. A further 52,000 children (45 per cent girls) living in humanitarian settings benefited from UNICEF support, resulting in sustained integration of refugee children into Rwanda’s national education system. A total of 4,500 pre-primary aged children (50.8 per cent girls) had opportunities to access quality education in a strengthened inclusive school environments and home settings, following the government-enforced school closures to prevent the COVID-19 pandemic.; | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2021
